SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

ukraine, russia, international, leopard 2, tank, weapon, conflict

Ukraine Has Reportedly Lost About 40 Leopard Tanks Since February 2022
======================================================================

[10:12 17.10.2024](/20241017/ "News archive")
 (Updated: 13:02 17.10.2024)

¬© AP Photo / Michael SohnA Leopard 2 tank as a part of weapons deliveries to Ukraine

![A Leopard 2 tank as a part of weapons deliveries to Ukraine - Sputnik Africa, 1920, 17.10.2024](https://cdn1.img.sputniknews.africa/img/07e8/07/0d/1067487443_0:0:3564:2004_1920x0_80_0_0_7733207e8d6471ece40fd505c0b45362.jpg "A Leopard 2 tank as a part of weapons deliveries to Ukraine")

¬© AP Photo / Michael Sohn

Subscribe

MOSCOW (Sputnik) - Ukraine has lost around 40 Leopard tanks since the beginning of Russia's special military operation in February 2022, the Business Insider news outlet reported on Thursday.

Some open-source estimates suggest that Ukraine had already [lost](https://en.sputniknews.africa/20241013/1068665538.html)
 nearly 40 Leopards, but those estimates are unconfirmed so far, according to the report.

Russia repeatedly stated that arms supplies to Ukraine hinder the settlement and directly involve NATO countries in the conflict. Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said that the United States and [NATO](https://en.sputniknews.africa/20240512/1066501213.html)
 were directly involved in the conflict not only by providing weapons but also by training Ukrainian personnel in European countries.

[![Leopard 2 and Bradley pictured among destroyed and damaged Ukrainian vehicles. Screenshot of Russian Defense Ministry video. - Sputnik Africa, 1920, 04.11.2023](https://cdn1.img.sputniknews.africa/img/07e7/08/05/1061086329_0:221:1360:765_1920x0_80_0_0_e3c9d50c9e4682697a50f5d445b1b805.jpg "Leopard 2 and Bradley pictured among destroyed and damaged Ukrainian vehicles. Screenshot of Russian Defense Ministry video.")](/20231104/quarter-of-leopard-2-tanks-written-off-by-ukraine-just-over-week-1063322121.html "Quarter of Leopard 2 Tanks 'Written Off' by Ukraine Just Over Week")

[Russia's Special Operation in Ukraine](/russias-special-operation-in-ukraine/ "Russia's Special Operation in Ukraine")

[Quarter of Leopard 2 Tanks 'Written Off' by Ukraine Just Over Week](/20231104/quarter-of-leopard-2-tanks-written-off-by-ukraine-just-over-week-1063322121.html "Quarter of Leopard 2 Tanks 'Written Off' by Ukraine Just Over Week")

4 November 2023, 15:10

By [AFP](https://www.themoscowtimes.com/author/afp "AFP")

June 13, 2023

! <image:2769>

Ukrainian Armed Forces destroyed in the Zaporozhye direction. Russian Defence Ministry / TASS

Moscow said Tuesday that it had captured several German Leopard tanks and U.S. Bradley infantry fighting vehicles, releasing footage showing Russian troops surveying the equipment supplied to Ukraine by Western countries.

"Leopard tanks and Bradley infantry fighting vehicles. These are our trophies. Equipment of the Ukrainian armed forces in the Zaporizhzhia region," the Russian Defense Ministry said in a statement.

"Servicemen of the Vostok group inspect enemy tanks and infantry fighting vehicles captured in battle."

Kyiv has appealed to its allies in the West to deliver a broad range of modern military equipment to help Ukrainian forces recapture large swathes of territory controlled by Russian forces.

The Defense Ministry said several of the captured vehicles had working engines, suggesting that the battles they were involved in had been short and that Ukrainian troops had "fled" their offensive positions.

From [Source](https://defencesecurityasia.com/en/german-made-leopard-tanks-bear-the-brunt-of-russian-forces-rejuvenation-in-ukraine/): Found exact image on website with title: German-Made Leopard Tanks Bear The Brunt of Russian Forces ...
Content: "[!Defence Security Asia <image:2775>](https://defencesecurityasia.com/en/home-en/)

German-Made Leopard Tanks Bear The Brunt of Russian Forces‚Äô ‚ÄúRejuvenation‚Äù in Ukraine‚Äù
======================================================================================

In addition to the Leopard tanks, the Russian Ministry of Defense also alleged that 13 armored vehicles, 55 various vehicles, "Grad" multiple rocket launcher systems, and 47 artillery units‚Äî22 of which were supplied by foreign countries‚Äîwere destroyed during this period.

[Technology](https://defencesecurityasia.com/en/category/technology/)

[By **admin**](https://defencesecurityasia.com/en/author/dsa-a/ "Browse Author Articles")
 On **May 19, 2024**

 <image:2776>

The captured Ukrainian's Leopard 2A6 main battle tanks on its way to Moscow.

[](https://reddit.com/submit?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdefencesecurityasia.com%2Fen%2Fgerman-made-leopard-tanks-bear-the-brunt-of-russian-forces-rejuvenation-in-ukraine%2F&title=German-Made Leopard Tanks Bear The Brunt of Russian Forces‚Äô ‚ÄúRejuvenation‚Äù in Ukraine‚Äù)
[](whatsapp://send?text=German-Made Leopard Tanks Bear The Brunt of Russian Forces‚Äô ‚ÄúRejuvenation‚Äù in Ukraine‚Äù %0A%0A https%3A%2F%2Fdefencesecurityasia.com%2Fen%2Fgerman-made-leopard-tanks-bear-the-brunt-of-russian-forces-rejuvenation-in-ukraine%2F)
[](https://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdefencesecurityasia.com%2Fen%2Fgerman-made-leopard-tanks-bear-the-brunt-of-russian-forces-rejuvenation-in-ukraine%2F&media=https://i0.wp.com/defencesecurityasia.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/20240423_000828-1.jpg?fit=640%2C427&ssl=1&description=German-Made Leopard Tanks Bear The Brunt of Russian Forces‚Äô ‚ÄúRejuvenation‚Äù in Ukraine‚Äù)
[](/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#)

**(DEFENCE SECURITY ASIA) ‚Äî During the week of May 11 to 17, Russian military claimed to have successfully destroyed five Leopard 2A1 tanks, manufactured by the German company Krauss-Maffei but donated to the Ukrainian Armed Forces to help the Eastern Europe country in its armed conflict with Russia.**

**In addition to the Leopard tanks, the Russian Ministry of Defense also alleged that 13 armored vehicles, 55 various vehicles, ‚ÄúGrad‚Äù multiple rocket launcher systems, and 47 artillery units‚Äî22 of which were supplied by foreign countries‚Äîwere destroyed during this period.**

**Moreover, four Mi-24 helicopters and 40 unmanned boats belonging to the Ukrainian military were reportedly destroyed by Russia in the same timeframe.**

**Among the foreign-supplied armored vehicles to Ukraine, the Leopard tanks have been the most frequently supplied to Kyiv compared to other models such as the American-made Abrams and the British-made Challengers.**

**Since last year, countries such as Germany and several other European nations have supplied between 100-200 Leopard tanks to Ukraine for use in a spring counteroffensive against Russian positions.**

**‚ÄúRussian Soldiers Pose in Front of Captured Leopard 2A6 Tank‚Äù**

**Line of Leopard tanks and Bradley armoured infantry fighting vehicle were destroyed in Zaphorizia, southern Ukraine.**

**Although the Ukrainian counteroffensive in 2023 initially started well, it faced increasingly formidable opposition from Russian forces who began altering their tactics and strategies.**

**These changes in strategy and tactics by the Russian forces led to the destruction of many of the Ukrainian tanks that had been supplied by donor countries like Germany, other European nations, the United States, and Britain.**

**However, to date, no one knows exactly how many Leopard tanks have been destroyed by Russia.**

**Nevertheless, Russian President Vladimir Putin has reportedly stated to his country‚Äôs war correspondents that Ukraine has lost more than 160 tanks supplied by foreign countries.**

**Given the high volume of Leopard tanks supplied to Ukraine, it is logical to conclude that many of the tanks destroyed by Russia were Leopard models.**

**Regarding the Abrams tanks, the Russian military stated that of the 31 American-made tanks supplied to Ukraine, more than five of the tanks have been destroyed by Russian forces.**

**A charred M1A1 Abrams main battle tank being transported to Moscow to participate in an exhibition at Victory Park.**

¬†**As a result of the destruction of five Abrams tanks, the United States has reportedly ‚Äúwithdrawn‚Äù these tanks from the Ukrainian battlefield, likely in an effort to ‚Äúpreserve its reputation.‚Äù**

**Following the destruction experienced by Leopard tanks supplied by Germany and other European countries, Ukraine‚Äôs Deputy Foreign Minister Andii Melnyk has requested that Kiev be supplied with more Leopard tanks, including the latest variant, the Leopard 2A6.**

¬†**However, the newest Leopard 2A6 variant supplied to Ukraine has met the same fate.**

**The Russian military reported capturing the most powerful tank in the Ukrainian arsenal, the German-made Leopard 2A6, after intense fighting in Avdiivka, Ukraine, last April.**

**It is believed that Ukraine possesses 21 Leopard 2A6 tanks, with 18 of these tanks developed by the companies Krauss-Maffei Wegmann and Rheinmetall being donated by Germany, while the remainder were provided by Portugal.**

**However, most of these Leopard 2A6 tanks donated to the Ukrainian military could not be used after failing to be properly maintained and remained inoperable as claimed by a senior German politician last January.**

**An Abrams tank caught fire after being struck by a Lancet kamikaze drone and an RPG from Russian forces.**

**According to Russian military sources, after capturing and removing the tank from the combat area, Russian forces transported the tank and sent it to Moscow, possibly for research purposes.**

**The Leopard 2A6 was successfully captured after a Russian platoon executed an ambush that caused the Ukrainian tank crew to abandon the German-made vehicle.**

**The Leopard 2A6 represents an upgrade from the Leopard 2A5, incorporating enhanced armor protection, firepower, and electronic warfare capabilities.**

**The tank measures 9.97 meters in length and weighs 62.3 tons, making it one of the heaviest main battle tanks ever deployed, with an engine power of 1,500 horsepower.**

**Capable of speeds up to 75 km/h and with an operational range of 500 km, it is equipped with a Rheinmetall 120 mm L/55 cannon, allowing it to fire all standard NATO ammunition types, including APFSDS, HEAT, and multi-purpose shells.**

**The Leopard 2A6 also features dual 7.62 mm MG3A1 machine guns and an advanced fire control system including a laser rangefinder, thermal imaging, and a ballistic computer. ‚Äî DSA**

[featured](https://defencesecurityasia.com/en/tag/featured-en/)
[German](https://defencesecurityasia.com/en/tag/german/)

You cannot print contents of this website."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The article from Defence Security Asia, published on May 19, 2024, discusses the destruction of Leopard tanks in Ukraine. It mentions that the Russian military claimed to have destroyed five Leopard 2A1 tanks between May 11 and 17, 2024. The article also includes an image of a captured Leopard 2A6 tank. <image:2776> The article does not mention any Ukrainian incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast.

_________________________



SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:26> This image shows destroyed Ukrainian tanks during Ukraine's incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:26>)
web_search("Ukraine Russia Kursk Oblast August 2024 tanks destroyed")
```

## Web Sources
**Reverse Search Result** The exact image was found in the following sources:

From [Source](https://en.sputniknews.africa/20241017/ukraine-has-reportedly-lost-about-40-leopard-tanks-since-february-2022-1068726197.html): Found exact image on website with title: Ukraine Has Reportedly Lost About 40 Leopard Tanks Since ...
Content: The search result from Sputnik Africa, published on October 17, 2024, reports that Ukraine has lost around 40 Leopard tanks since the beginning of Russia's special military operation in February 2022. The article includes an image of a Leopard 2 tank <image:2767>, <image:2768>. The article also mentions that Russia repeatedly stated that arms supplies to Ukraine hinder the settlement and directly involve NATO countries in the conflict.


From [Source](https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2023/06/13/russia-says-german-leopard-tanks-us-bradleys-captured-in-ukraine-a81492): Found exact image on website with title: Russia Says German Leopard Tanks, U.S. Bradleys Captured in ...
Content: The Moscow Times published an article on June 13, 2023, stating that Russia had captured German Leopard tanks and U.S. Bradley infantry fighting vehicles in the Zaporizhzhia region. <image:2769> shows destroyed tanks. The article does not mention Ukraine's incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024.


From [Source](https://defencesecurityasia.com/en/german-made-leopard-tanks-bear-the-brunt-of-russian-forces-rejuvenation-in-ukraine/): Found exact image on website with title: German-Made Leopard Tanks Bear The Brunt of Russian Forces ...
Content: The article from Defence Security Asia, published on May 19, 2024, discusses the destruction of Leopard tanks in Ukraine. It mentions that the Russian military claimed to have destroyed five Leopard 2A1 tanks between May 11 and 17, 2024. The article also includes an image of a captured Leopard 2A6 tank. <image:2776> The article does not mention any Ukrainian incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The reverse image search found the image in multiple sources. One source, from Sputnik Africa, published on October 17, 2024, reports that Ukraine has lost around 40 Leopard tanks since February 2022. The Moscow Times published an article on June 13, 2023, stating that Russia had captured German Leopard tanks in the Zaporizhzhia region. Defence Security Asia published an article on May 19, 2024, discussing the destruction of Leopard tanks in Ukraine. None of the sources mention Ukraine's incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024.

The sources include images of Leopard tanks <image:2767>, <image:2768>, <image:2769>, and <image:2776>.

_________________________



SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

[Ocheretyne](/wiki/Battle_of_Ocheretyne "Battle of Ocheretyne")<br>    <br>*   **[3rd Kharkiv](/wiki/2024_Kharkiv_offensive "2024 Kharkiv offensive")<br>    **<br>    *   [Kharkiv strikes](/wiki/Kharkiv_strikes_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Kharkiv strikes (2022‚Äìpresent)")<br>        <br>*   **[Toretsk](/wiki/Battle_of_Toretsk "Battle of Toretsk")<br>    **<br>*   **[Pokrovsk](/wiki/Pokrovsk_offensive "Pokrovsk offensive")<br>    **<br>    *   [Dobropillia](/wiki/Dobropillia_offensive "Dobropillia offensive")<br>        <br>*   **[Kurakhove](/wiki/Battle_of_Kurakhove "Battle of Kurakhove")<br>    **<br>*   [Velyka Novosilka](/wiki/Velyka_Novosilka_offensive "Velyka Novosilka offensive")<br>    <br>*   **[Novopavlivka](/wiki/Novopavlivka_offensive "Novopavlivka offensive")<br>    **<br><br>* * *<br><br>**[Southern front](/wiki/Southern_front_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Southern front of the Russian invasion of Ukraine")<br>**<br><br>*   **[Dnieper](/wiki/Dnieper_campaign_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Dnieper campaign (2022‚Äìpresent)")<br>    **<br>    *   [Krynky](/wiki/Battle_of_Krynky "Battle of Krynky")<br>        <br><br>* * *<br><br>**Ukrainian incursion**<br><br>*   **[Kursk](/wiki/2024_Kursk_offensive "2024 Kursk offensive")<br>    **<br>    *   [Olgovskiy Forest](/wiki/Battle_of_Olgovskiy_Forest "Battle of Olgovskiy Forest")<br>        <br>    *   _[Stream](/wiki/Operation_Stream "Operation Stream")<br>        _<br>*   [Belgorod incursion](/wiki/2025_Belgorod_incursion "2025 Belgorod incursion")<br>    <br>*   [Tyotkino incursion](/wiki/2025_Tyotkino_incursion "2025 Tyotkino incursion")<br>    <br><br>* * *<br><br>**Other regions**<br><br>*   [Strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure](/wiki/Russian_strikes_against_Ukrainian_infrastructure_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Russian strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure (2022‚Äìpresent)")<br>    <br><br>* * *<br><br>**Naval operations**<br><br>*   [Tendra Spit](/wiki/Raid_on_Tendra_Spit "Raid on Tendra Spit")<br>    <br><br>* * *<br><br>**Spillover & related incidents**<br><br>*   [Western Russia](/wiki/Attacks_in_Russia_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Attacks in Russia during the Russian invasion of Ukraine")<br>    *   [May 2024 Belgorod missile strike](/wiki/May_2024_Belgorod_missile_strike "May 2024 Belgorod missile strike")<br>        <br>    *   [March 2024 western Russia incursion](/wiki/March_2024_western_Russia_incursion "March 2024 western Russia incursion")<br>        <br>*   [2024 Ukrainian coup attempt allegations](/wiki/2024_Ukrainian_coup_attempt_allegations "2024 Ukrainian coup attempt allegations")<br>    <br>*   [2024 Ukrainian cyberattacks against Russia](/wiki/2024_Ukrainian_cyberattacks_against_Russia "2024 Ukrainian cyberattacks against Russia")<br>    <br>*   [Toropets explosions](/wiki/Toropets_depot_explosions "Toropets depot explosions")<br>    <br>*   [North Korean involvement](/wiki/North_Korean_involvement_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "North Korean involvement in the Russian invasion of Ukraine")<br>    <br>*   [Azerbaijan Airlines Flight 8243](/wiki/Azerbaijan_Airlines_Flight_8243 "Azerbaijan Airlines Flight 8243")<br>    <br>*   _[Spider's Web](/wiki/Operation_Spider%27s_Web "Operation Spider's Web")<br>    _ |     |

On 6 August 2024, during the [Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine")
,[\[36\]](#cite_note-dw.com-38)
[\[37\]](#cite_note-ft.com-39)
\[_[failed verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")\
 ‚Äì [see discussion](/wiki/Talk:Kursk_campaign#A_ridiculous_edit "Talk:Kursk campaign")\
_\] part of the [Russo-Ukrainian War](/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War "Russo-Ukrainian War")
, the [Armed Forces of Ukraine](/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Ukraine "Armed Forces of Ukraine")
 launched an incursion into [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia")
's [Kursk Oblast](/wiki/Kursk_Oblast "Kursk Oblast")
 and clashed with the [Russian Armed Forces](/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces "Russian Armed Forces")
 and [Russian border guard](/wiki/FSB_Border_Service_of_Russia "FSB Border Service of Russia")
.[\[38\]](#cite_note-REU86-40)
[\[36\]](#cite_note-dw.com-38)
[\[37\]](#cite_note-ft.com-39)
 A [state of emergency](/wiki/State_of_emergency_in_Russia "State of emergency in Russia")
 was declared in Kursk Oblast,[\[39\]](#cite_note-BBC_8_Aug-41)
 and Russian reserves were rushed to the area.[\[40\]](#cite_note-BBC_Cursino-42)
 By the end of the first week, the Ukrainian military said it had captured 1,000¬†km2 (390¬†sq¬†mi) of Russian territory, while Russian authorities acknowledged that Ukraine had captured 28 settlements.[\[41\]](#cite_note-43)

In the second half of August the front stabilized,[\[42\]](#cite_note-forbes_20240911-44)
 and in early October, the Ukrainian advance had stalled.[\[11\]](#cite_note-CNN_Third_Month-12)
 From November, North Korean forces were sent to the province to support the Russian military. According to Russia, the incursion involved around 300 Ukrainian troops, 11 tanks, and over 20 [armored combat vehicles](/wiki/Armoured_fighting_vehicle "Armoured fighting vehicle")
,[\[67\]](#cite_note-MT86-69)
 and was aimed in two directions: at [Oleshnya](/wiki/Oleshnya,_Kursk_Oblast "Oleshnya, Kursk Oblast")
 in the direction of [Sudzha](/wiki/Sudzha "Sudzha")
, east-northeast of [Sumy](/wiki/Sumy "Sumy")
, and towards [Nikolayevo-Darino](/wiki/Nikolayevo-Darino "Nikolayevo-Darino")
, north-northeast of Sumy.[\[68\]](#cite_note-ISW_August_6-70)
 It was reported that Chechen [Akhmat battalions](/wiki/Russian_irregular_units_in_Ukraine#Akhmat_battalions "Russian irregular units in Ukraine")
 were responding to the raids,[\[68\]](#cite_note-ISW_August_6-70)
 though these claims remained unverified as of 13 September 2024.[\[69\]](#cite_note-71)

The attack began at 08:00 [MSK](/wiki/Moscow_Time "Moscow Time")
. [Alexei Smirnov](/wiki/Alexei_Smirnov_(politician) "Alexei Smirnov (politician)")
, acting [governor of Kursk Oblast](/wiki/Governor_of_Kursk_Oblast "Governor of Kursk Oblast")
, reported that three people died during the events: a woman in the border incursion and two individuals in separate drone attacks.[\[70\]](#cite_note-72)
 Russian [milbloggers](/wiki/Milblog "Milblog")
 also largely dismissed the supposed raids as "unsuccessful" and a "media stunt".[\[68\]](#cite_note-ISW_August_6-70)

According to Russia, at least 1,000 troops crossed the border on the first day, supported by [tanks](/wiki/Tank "Tank")
 and armored vehicles.[\[39\]](#cite_note-BBC_8_Aug-41)
 According to Andrzej Wilk of the [Centre for Eastern Studies](/wiki/Centre_for_Eastern_Studies "Centre for Eastern Studies")
, the entire Ukrainian grouping, including some elements which did not cross over into Russia, consisted of an estimated 2,000 men from Ukraine's [22nd](/wiki/22nd_Mechanized_Brigade_(Ukraine) "22nd Mechanized Brigade (Ukraine)")
 and [82nd](/wiki/82nd_Air_Assault_Brigade_(Ukraine) "82nd Air Assault Brigade (Ukraine)")
 Brigades, supported by artillery and air defense sub-units.[\[66\]](#cite_note-wilk-68)
 It was later claimed by members of the Ukrainian military that the breakthrough on the border was conducted by the 80th and 82nd Air Assault Brigades.[\[64\]](#cite_note-Kyrylenko-66)

Russian milbloggers claimed that the offensive was being performed by the [Russian Volunteer Corps](/wiki/Russian_Volunteer_Corps "Russian Volunteer Corps")
 (RVC), while the _[New Voice of Ukraine](/wiki/New_Voice_of_Ukraine "New Voice of Ukraine")
_ citing a source in [Ukraine's Main Military Intelligence](/wiki/Ukraine%27s_Main_Military_Intelligence "Ukraine's Main Military Intelligence")
 reported that the RVC was not present.[\[68\]](#cite_note-ISW_August_6-70)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D1%82_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%A1%D0%A3_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%9A%D1%83%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%8E_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C.jpg/250px-%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D1%82_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%A1%D0%A3_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%9A%D1%83%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%8E_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D1%82_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%92%D0%A1%D0%A3_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%9A%D1%83%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%8E_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C.jpg)

Building damaged in Kursk Oblast, 6¬†August 2024

#### 7 August

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Ukrainian_%22Southern_Railway%22_1943.jpg/250px-Ukrainian_%22Southern_Railway%22_1943.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ukrainian_%22Southern_Railway%22_1943.jpg)

1943 Ukrainian railway map shows Sudzha in quadrant A2 at km 60 on the [Lgov](/wiki/Lgov,_Kursk_Oblast "Lgov, Kursk Oblast")
‚Äì[Gotnya](/wiki/Gotnya "Gotnya")
‚Äì[Zolochiv](/wiki/Zolochiv,_Kharkiv_Oblast "Zolochiv, Kharkiv Oblast")
 main line to [Kharkiv](/wiki/Kharkiv "Kharkiv")

A milblogger claimed that Ukrainian forces had captured 11 settlements and had advanced 14 kilometres (9¬†mi) deep into the oblast.[\[71\]](#cite_note-NBC87-73)
 Government agencies were ordered by President [Vladimir Putin](/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin")
 to "provide the needed assistance to residents", and deputy prime minister [Denis Manturov](/wiki/Denis_Manturov "Denis Manturov")
 was sent to oversee their work.[\[72\]](#cite_note-mt1-74)
 Kursk Oblast was placed under a [state of emergency](/wiki/State_of_emergency "State of emergency")
 by governor Smirnov.[\[73\]](#cite_note-dw1-75)
[\[74\]](#cite_note-CNBC_State_of_Emergency-76)

Putin met with key members of the security establishment including [Valery Gerasimov](/wiki/Valery_Gerasimov "Valery Gerasimov")
, [Alexander Bortnikov](/wiki/Alexander_Bortnikov "Alexander Bortnikov")
, [Sergei Shoigu](/wiki/Sergei_Shoigu "Sergei Shoigu")
 and [Andrey Belousov](/wiki/Andrey_Belousov "Andrey Belousov")
 on the Kursk incursion.[\[75\]](#cite_note-kru1-77)
 Gerasimov told Putin that about 1,000 Ukrainian soldiers took part in the attack and that their advance had been halted.[\[74\]](#cite_note-CNBC_State_of_Emergency-76)
[\[76\]](#cite_note-Reuters_Videos_show_Ukrainian_Presence-78)

Geolocated footage confirmed that Ukrainian forces had advanced at least 10 kilometres (6.2¬†mi) across the Russian border, having penetrated at least two Russian defensive lines and a stronghold. Russian officials said that the loss of the bridge would hinder the relocation via land routes of civilians in the district.[\[151\]](#cite_note-153)
[\[152\]](#cite_note-154)
 Approximately 2,000 to 3,000 Russian conscripts were trapped in a [pocket](/wiki/Pocket_(military) "Pocket (military)")
 south of the river.[\[153\]](#cite_note-155)

#### 17 August

Russian forces reportedly blew up two bridges near [Tyotkino](/wiki/Tyotkino "Tyotkino")
 and [Popovo-Lezhachi](/wiki/Popovo-Lezhachi "Popovo-Lezhachi")
 after withdrawing from the right bank of the [Seym River](/wiki/Seym_River "Seym River")
 in the area.[\[154\]](#cite_note-156)

The Ukrainian military claimed the capture of the settlement of [Korenevo](/wiki/Korenevo,_Korenevsky_District,_Kursk_Oblast "Korenevo, Korenevsky District, Kursk Oblast")
 but the Russian MOD described the settlement as contested.[\[155\]](#cite_note-157)

#### 18 August

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/The_80th_Air_Assault_Brigade_captured_a_T-90M_Proryv_tank_in_the_Kursk_region.jpg/250px-The_80th_Air_Assault_Brigade_captured_a_T-90M_Proryv_tank_in_the_Kursk_region.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_80th_Air_Assault_Brigade_captured_a_T-90M_Proryv_tank_in_the_Kursk_region.jpg)

Ukrainian soldiers with a captured Russian [T-90](/wiki/T-90 "T-90")
M Proryv tank

Ukrainian forces destroyed another bridge over the [Seym](/wiki/Seym_(river) "Seym (river)")
 river near [Zvannoye](/wiki/Zvannoye "Zvannoye")
.[\[156\]](#cite_note-158)
[\[157\]](#cite_note-ISW_2024-08-16-159)
[\[158\]](#cite_note-160)

According to Russian bloggers, both Ukraine and Russia reinforced their forces battling in Kursk Oblast, with Russia moving some forces from other fronts to the front.[\[159\]](#cite_note-newsweek20240818-161)
\[_[better¬†source¬†needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")\
_\]

Marines from the [501st Separate Naval Infantry Battalion](/wiki/501st_Separate_Naval_Infantry_Battalion "501st Separate Naval Infantry Battalion")
 posted a video of them tearing down the Russian flag from the municipal building of [Apanasovka](/wiki/Apanasovka,_Korenevsky_District,_Kursk_Oblast "Apanasovka, Korenevsky District, Kursk Oblast")
.[\[160\]](#cite_note-162)

#### 19 August

Russia claimed that the Ukrainian military destroyed the third and last bridge over the Seym River in [Korenevsky District](/wiki/Korenevsky_District "Korenevsky District")
 leading to possible logistical strain on over 700 square kilometers of Russian territory.[\[161\]](#cite_note-163)

In his evening address, President Zelenskyy said that Ukrainian forces were in control of 92 settlements in Kursk Oblast and 1,250 square kilometers of Russian territory.[\[162\]](#cite_note-164)

#### 20 August

The Russian interior ministry warned residents of Bryansk, Kursk and Belgorod Oblasts against using online dating websites and security cameras, citing concerns of information being gathered by Ukrainian forces.[\[163\]](#cite_note-165)
 [Yunus-Bek Yevkurov](/wiki/Yunus-Bek_Yevkurov "Yunus-Bek Yevkurov")
, former head of [Ingushetia](/wiki/Ingushetia "Ingushetia")
 and incumbent deputy head of the Ministry of Defense was appointed as [Andrei Belousov](/wiki/Andrei_Belousov "Andrei Belousov")
's deputy in the Coordinating Council for the Security Issues of the Bordering Territories. Some officials hoped it could be the first step toward a more comprehensive peace deal.[\[306\]](#cite_note-washingtonpost-qatar-308)
 Russian foreign ministry spokesperson [Maria Zakharova](/wiki/Maria_Zakharova "Maria Zakharova")
 said that there were "no direct or indirect negotiations between Russia and Ukraine on the safety of civilian critical infrastructure facilities" and that after the assault on Kursk Oblast, Putin ruled out the possibility of such talks.[\[396\]](#cite_note-euractiv-qatar-398)
[\[397\]](#cite_note-399)
 A Russian academic with close ties to senior Russian diplomats said that Putin probably lost interest in further talks in Qatar because the "Russian leadership usually does not make any compromises under pressure" and attacks on energy infrastructure are highly effective tactics that do more damage to Ukraine than to Russia, adding that Russia is more interested in talks with Ukraine about a broader ceasefire.[\[306\]](#cite_note-washingtonpost-qatar-308)

The level of anxiety among Russians was much less than that after the [2022 mobilization](/wiki/2022_Russian_mobilization "2022 Russian mobilization")
, according to a [Levada](/wiki/Levada_Center "Levada Center")
 poll.[\[389\]](#cite_note-Sort-391)
[\[398\]](#cite_note-Levada2024-400)

The incursion led the [Russian Central Election Commission](/wiki/Central_Election_Commission_(Russia) "Central Election Commission (Russia)")
 to postpone voting for the [2024 Russian elections](/wiki/2024_Russian_elections "2024 Russian elections")
 in seven municipalities located in occupied areas of Kursk Oblast that were originally scheduled for 6‚Äì8 September.[\[399\]](#cite_note-401)
 In Belgorod Oblast, authorities ordered the start of classes in September to be held online in areas within 20 kilometers of the Ukrainian border.[\[400\]](#cite_note-402)

According to BBC journalists, Russian soldiers in territories of Kursk Oblast near the front engaged in [looting](/wiki/Looting "Looting")
.[\[401\]](#cite_note-403)

Casualties
----------

### Russia

Ukraine claimed their forces had shot down an [Mi-28](/wiki/Mil_Mi-28 "Mil Mi-28")
 and two [Ka-52](/wiki/Ka-52 "Ka-52")
[\[23\]](#cite_note-KI86-24)
[\[24\]](#cite_note-Ka52-2-25)
 helicopters.[\[402\]](#cite_note-Mi28-404)

On 9 August 2024, [HIMARS](/wiki/M142_HIMARS "M142 HIMARS")
 destroyed a convoy of Russian troops in Kursk Oblast in what Russian milbloggers described as one of the bloodiest attacks of the entire war.[\[95\]](#cite_note-telegraph-column-97)
[\[403\]](#cite_note-405)

On 12 August, Ukrainian military expert Mykhailo Zhirokhov claimed that the ratio of Ukrainian to Russian manpower losses as "closer to 1 to 10", and the number of Russian POWs taken as "thousands".[\[404\]](#cite_note-406)
 Since most of the best Russian troops were deployed in Ukraine, most of the Russian soldiers protecting the Russian border in the Kursk region were young, inexperienced [conscripts](/wiki/Conscription_in_Russia "Conscription in Russia")
 who suffered heavy losses in combat with experienced Ukrainian troops.[\[390\]](#cite_note-thebarentsobserver-392)
[\[59\]](#cite_note-cnn-conscripts-61)

On 19 August, the Ukrainian resistance group [Atesh](/wiki/Atesh "Atesh")
 claimed that a battalion from the [810th Guards Naval Infantry Brigade](/wiki/810th_Guards_Naval_Infantry_Brigade "810th Guards Naval Infantry Brigade")
 had suffered heavy losses and had only 30% of its combat personnel left.[\[405\]](#cite_note-407)
 According to a Western official, about 1,000 Russian soldiers were killed or wounded daily in the fighting in Kursk and Donbas.[\[406\]](#cite_note-408)

As of 23 September 2024, Russian officials reported that at least 56 civilians had been killed since the start of the incursion, while at least 266 others, including 11 children, had been injured.[\[407\]](#cite_note-56dead-409)
 The Russian state broadcaster [Russia-24](/wiki/Russia-24 "Russia-24")
 announced that one of its reporters, [Evgeniy Poddubny](/wiki/Evgeniy_Poddubny "Evgeniy Poddubny")
, had been injured in a drone attack on his vehicle while reporting on the fighting in the affected areas on 7 August.[\[408\]](#cite_note-410)
 On 16 August, the [All-Russia People's Front](/wiki/All-Russia_People%27s_Front "All-Russia People's Front")
 said that one of its medical staff and a media coordinator had been killed after their vehicle was shelled while assisting in evacuation efforts.[\[409\]](#cite_note-411)
 At least 770 residents of Kursk Oblast went missing following the incursion.[\[407\]](#cite_note-56dead-409)
 Around 20,000 civilians are believed to be living under Ukrainian occupation in the oblast.[\[410\]](#cite_note-412)
 In October 2024, Russian human rights commissioner [Tatyana Moskalkova](/wiki/Tatyana_Moskalkova "Tatyana Moskalkova")
 accused Ukraine of forcibly taking more than 1,000 residents of Kursk Oblast.[\[411\]](#cite_note-413)

On 25 October 2024, Ukrainian Commander-in-Chief Colonel-General [Oleksandr Syrskyi](/wiki/Oleksandr_Syrskyi "Oleksandr Syrskyi")
 claimed Russian soldiers had suffered 17,819 casualties since 8 August 2024, of which 6,662 had been killed, 10,446 wounded and 711 captured.[\[412\]](#cite_note-414)

On 10 November, the Ukrainian 95th Airborne Assault Brigade claimed to have repelled an assault by the Russian [810th Marine Brigade](/wiki/810th_Naval_Infantry_Brigade "810th Naval Infantry Brigade")
, killing 100 and wounding 100 personnel in two days, while also destroying 28 pieces of equipment.[\[413\]](#cite_note-c010-415)

On 20 November, the Ukrainian [80th Air Assault Brigade](/wiki/80th_Air_Assault_Brigade_(Ukraine) "80th Air Assault Brigade (Ukraine)")
 claimed to have captured 26 Russian soldiers in a single battle on Kursk Oblast.[\[414\]](#cite_note-h833-416)

On 27 December, the South Korean [National Intelligence Service](/wiki/National_Intelligence_Service_(South_Korea) "National Intelligence Service (South Korea)")
 said that a North Korean soldier had been taken prisoner by Ukrainian forces for the first time in Kursk Oblast. Khinstein said that the bodies of killed civilians in the region were being recovered, but gave no details on how they had died.[\[32\]](#cite_note-mt288-34)

### Ukraine

Russia claimed that six Ukrainian tanks and ten armored vehicles were lost in the initial engagement on 6 August.[\[67\]](#cite_note-MT86-69)
[\[425\]](#cite_note-Novaya-427)
[\[426\]](#cite_note-UkrRetreat2-428)
 Acting governor of Kursk Oblast, [Alexei Smirnov](/wiki/Alexei_Smirnov_(politician) "Alexei Smirnov (politician)")
, claimed that 26 Ukrainian UAVs were shot down in the area.[\[427\]](#cite_note-nocomment-429)
 Russia later claimed on 9 August, that Ukraine had losses of 945 soldiers and 102 armored vehicles, although this could not be verified.[\[76\]](#cite_note-Reuters_Videos_show_Ukrainian_Presence-78)

On 17 August, Forbes reported "heavy Ukrainian equipment write-offs compared to relatively few Russian write-offs."[\[428\]](#cite_note-430)

[DeepStateMap.Live](/wiki/DeepStateMap.Live "DeepStateMap.Live")
 reported that nine Ukrainian "drone operators and contractors" were shot after surrendering to Russian forces on 10 October.[\[429\]](#cite_note-431)

As of 7 August 2025, UALosses listed Ukrainian casualties during the Kursk campaign as 2,588 dead, 9,622 missing and 306 captured Ukrainian soldiers.[\[430\]](#cite_note-432)

.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Kursk_front_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War.svg/330px-Kursk_front_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Kursk_front_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War.svg)

**Per OSINT:**  
c. By the end of August, the operation began to be criticized for diverting Ukrainian forces from [the east](/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine_campaign "Eastern Ukraine campaign")
, stretching Ukraine's personnel along the front and allowing Russia to [advance toward Pokrovsk](/wiki/Pokrovsk_offensive "Pokrovsk offensive")
.[\[46\]](#cite_note-AlexHorton-48)
[\[47\]](#cite_note-Miller-49)
 The [Institute for the Study of War](/wiki/Institute_for_the_Study_of_War "Institute for the Study of War")
 reported that Russia had moved forces from "lower-priority" areas, but not from Donetsk Oblast.[\[48\]](#cite_note-50)

The Ukrainian incursion into Kursk surprised Russia, some of Ukraine's allies, and many in the Ukrainian elite.[\[40\]](#cite_note-BBC_Cursino-42)
[\[49\]](#cite_note-ap_20240814-51)
[\[50\]](#cite_note-guardiansept-52)
 It is the most significant attack across the border since the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine,[\[51\]](#cite_note-53)
 and the first carried out primarily by Ukrainian regular forces. Additionally, there were reports of fighting in [Ivnitsa](/w/index.php?title=Ivnitsa&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ivnitsa (page does not exist)")
¬†\[[ru](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%98%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B0_(%D0%9A%D1%83%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C) "ru:–ò–≤–Ω–∏—Ü–∞ (–ö—É—Ä—Å–∫–∞—è –æ–±–ª–∞—Å—Ç—å)")\
; [uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%86%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8F_(%D0%9A%D1%83%D1%80%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C) "uk:–Ü–≤–Ω–∏—Ü—è (–ö—É—Ä—Å—å–∫–∞ –æ–±–ª–∞—Å—Ç—å)")\
\], a village 24¬†km (15¬†mi) from the border.[\[79\]](#cite_note-Politico_August_8-81)
 Russian sources claimed that Ukrainian forces had reached the village of [Darino](/wiki/Darino,_Kursk_Oblast "Darino, Kursk Oblast")
.[\[80\]](#cite_note-82)

#### 8 August

[RIA Novosti](/wiki/RIA_Novosti "RIA Novosti")
 reported that four people died as a result of 'attacks' by the [AFU](/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Ukraine "Armed Forces of Ukraine")
 in the oblast[\[81\]](#cite_note-Rai_2024-08-08-2-83)
 as fighting continued for the third day.[\[82\]](#cite_note-Reuters_2024-08-08-84)
[\[83\]](#cite_note-AlJazeera_2024-08-08-85)
 Pro-Russian milblogger Yuri Podolyaka said that "Sudzha is basically lost to us" and that Ukrainian forces were pushing towards [Lgov](/wiki/Lgov,_Kursk_Oblast "Lgov, Kursk Oblast")
.[\[84\]](#cite_note-86)

Ukrainian forces were in control of the western part of Sudzha and the surrounding roads; skirmishes continued in the town.[\[85\]](#cite_note-agent-87)

According to Smirnov, the acting governor of Kursk Oblast, six Ukrainian drones and five missiles were shot down during the night and morning.[\[86\]](#cite_note-meduzalive8aug-88)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/President_Vladimir_Putin_talks_with_the_governor_of_Kursk_in_August_2024.jpg/250px-President_Vladimir_Putin_talks_with_the_governor_of_Kursk_in_August_2024.jpg)](/wiki/File:President_Vladimir_Putin_talks_with_the_governor_of_Kursk_in_August_2024.jpg)

 talks with [Alexei Smirnov](/wiki/Alexei_Smirnov_(politician) "Alexei Smirnov (politician)")
, the acting [governor of Kursk](/wiki/Governor_of_Kursk_Oblast "Governor of Kursk Oblast")
, about the situation regarding the Ukrainian incursion. Skirmishes took place in the village of [Snagost](/wiki/Snagost,_Kursk_Oblast "Snagost, Kursk Oblast")
.[\[87\]](#cite_note-agents430–∫–º-89)
 Ukrainian troops were present in areas 35 kilometers from the Ukrainian border.[\[88\]](#cite_note-isw8-90)

#### 9 August

Reports claimed that Ukrainian troops had captured around 100[\[89\]](#cite_note-WP_Ukraine_stuns_Russia-91)
‚Äì200 square kilometers of territory, at a depth of around 10 kilometers on average.[\[90\]](#cite_note-92)
 Based on independent and own analyses, [CNN](/wiki/CNN "CNN")
 put the area of territory over which Russia had lost control at 250¬†square kilometers at least.[\[91\]](#cite_note-93)

A convoy of Russian troops was reportedly destroyed in a [HIMARS](/wiki/HIMARS "HIMARS")
 strike in the village of [Oktyabrskoye](/wiki/Oktyabrskoye,_Rylsky_District,_Kursk_Oblast "Oktyabrskoye, Rylsky District, Kursk Oblast")
 while moving along the route connecting [Glushkovsky District](/wiki/Glushkovsky_District "Glushkovsky District")
 and [Kursk](/wiki/Kursk "Kursk")
 and passing through [Rylsky](/wiki/Rylsky_District "Rylsky District")
 and [Lgovsky](/wiki/Lgovsky_District "Lgovsky District")
 districts."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result from Wikipedia discusses the 2024 Kursk offensive, which began on August 6, 2024, as part of the Russo-Ukrainian War. <image:26> The Armed Forces of Ukraine launched an incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast. The article mentions the involvement of Ukrainian, Russian, and North Korean forces, and provides casualty figures from both sides. The incursion led to a state of emergency in Kursk Oblast and the postponement of elections. The article also mentions the destruction of bridges and the capture of settlements.

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c0q198zyppqo): 
Content: "<image:4578>!Map showing the region of Sudzha in August 2024, controlled by Ukraine and on 16 March 2025, under Russian control <image:4581>

Volodymyr said it was possible to travel on that road relatively safely a month ago. On 13 March, Russia said the situation in Kursk was "fully under our control" and that Ukraine had "abandoned" much of its material.

BBC Verify: What does Putin video tell us about the battle for Kursk?

Dmytro: Inches from death
-------------------------

In social media posts on 11-12 March, a fourth soldier, "Dmytro" likened the retreat from the front to "a scene from a horror movie".

"The roads are littered with hundreds of destroyed cars, armoured vehicles and ATVs (All Terrain Vehicles). <image:4578>!Getty A damaged statue of Lenin stands in Sudzha after fighting in August <image:4587>Getty

A damaged statue of Lenin stands in Sudzha after fighting in August

What now for Ukraine's offensive?
---------------------------------

Ukraine's top general, Oleksandr Syrskyi, insists that Ukrainian forces have pulled back to "more favourable positions", remain in Kursk, and would do so "for as long as it is expedient and necessary".

He said Russia had suffered more than 50,000 losses during the operation - including those killed, injured or captured.

However, the situation now is very different to last August. <image:4578>!Getty Images A Ukrainian soldier comforts a comrade during fighting in Kursk <image:4579>Getty Images

A Ukrainian soldier comforts a comrade during fighting in Kursk

Ukrainian soldiers fighting in Russia's Kursk region have described scenes "like a horror movie" as they retreated from the front lines.

The BBC has received extensive accounts from Ukrainian troops, who recount a "catastrophic" withdrawal in the face of heavy fire, and columns of military equipment destroyed and constant attacks from swarms of Russian drones.

The soldiers, who spoke over social media, were given aliases to protect their identity. But this again came as a surprise to our command."

At the time of writing, just before Russia retook Sudzha, Volodymyr said Ukrainian forces were being pressed from three sides.

[Ukraine war in maps: How control has shifted in three years\
-----------------------------------------------------------](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-60506682)

[Peace talks are in parallel universe, say Ukraine front-line troops\
-------------------------------------------------------------------](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c89yqqd3n53o)

[Do Ukrainians believe a ceasefire with Russia will work?\
--------------------------------------------------------](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/videos/c4g7473l2lgo)

Maksym: Vehicle wrecks litter the roads
---------------------------------------

By 11 March, Ukrainian forces were battling to prevent the road being cut, according to Telegram messages from "Maksym".

"A few days ago, we received an order to leave the defence lines in an organised retreat," he said, adding that Russia had amassed a significant force to retake the town, "including large numbers of North Korean soldiers".

Military experts estimate Russia had amassed a force of up to 70,000 troops to retake Kursk ‚Äì including about 12,000 North Koreans.

Russia had also sent its best drone units to the front and was using kamikaze and first-person-view (FPV) variants to "take fire control of the main logistics routes".

They included drones linked to operators by fibre-optic wires - which are impossible to jam with electronic counter-measures.

Maksym said as a result "the enemy managed to destroy dozens of units of equipment", and that wrecks had "created congestion on supply routes".

! They were some of their best-trained soldiers, equipped with Western-supplied weapons including tanks and armoured vehicles.

Russian bloggers published videos showing some of that equipment being destroyed or captured. Military analysts estimate two-thirds of the 1,000 sq km gained at the outset have since been lost.

Any hopes that Ukraine would be able to trade Kursk territory for some of its own have significantly diminished.

Last week, President Volodymyr Zelensky said he believed the Kursk operation had "accomplished its task" by forcing Russia to pull troops from the east and relieve pressure on Pokrovsk.

But it is not yet clear at what cost.

'Everything is finished': Ukrainian troops relive retreat from Kursk

# Your Summary

The BBC published an article on March 17, 2025, discussing the retreat of Ukrainian troops from the Kursk region. The article mentions that the roads were littered with destroyed military equipment, including tanks and armored vehicles. <image:4578>, <image:4583>. The article also includes a map showing the Ukrainian advance in August 2024 and the subsequent Russian control by March 16, 2025. <image:4581>.

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.aljazeera.com/features/2024/8/29/russia-lashes-out-against-terrorist-incursion-in-kursk-pulls-back-planes): 
Content: "If in previous periods we had 30 to 50 antiaircraft missiles per day only \[in the Sumy region\], then yesterday the enemy used air strikes twice, using four antiaircraft missiles and 11 unguided air missiles.‚Äù

Units operating in hotly contested [Chasiv Yar](/news/2024/7/4/ukraine-army-retreats-from-part-of-strategic-chasiv-yar-as-russia-advances)
 in the eastern region of Donetsk have also reported a drop in glide bombs this month.

Vadym Mysnyk, a spokesman for the Siversk tactical group, said: ‚ÄúIt is a sign that we are thinning out their air force and hitting airfields, and we have pushed the enemy away from the border a little.‚Äù

![Kursk](/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/2024-08-08T164332Z_147386495_RC2SB9AWNB2F_RTRMADP_3_UKRAINE-CRISIS-RUSSIA-SUDZHA-1724945113.jpg?w=770&resize=770%2C433&quality=80)

A building is on fire in the town of Sudzha after a cross-border incursion of Ukrainian troops into the Kursk region of Russia in this still image from video taken on August 7, 2024 \[MIC Izvestia via Reuters\]

No effect on the Pokrovsk front
-------------------------------

There was also increasing evidence that Moscow was having trouble stopping the Ukrainian counterinvasion in Kursk and was increasingly tapping elite units to do so.

Russian military reporters and geolocated footage have revealed that elements of the 810th and 155th naval infantry brigades, the 11th Airborne Brigade, and the 51st and 56th airborne regiments were redeployed to fight in Kursk.

The 810th and 155th naval infantry brigades had been fighting in Kharkiv, where Russia launched a new incursion in May. Sarantsev admitted that the Kursk action had had no effect on the Pokrovsk front.

![Pokrovsk](/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/2024-08-24T151932Z_307779824_RC2EM9ARYVWH_RTRMADP_3_UKRAINE-CRISIS-POKROVSK-1724945269.jpg?w=770&resize=770%2C514&quality=80)

Ukrainian servicemen gather around a pick-up truck in Pokrovsk, Ukraine, as they prepare to move into battle against Russian troops 12km (7.5 miles) away on August 24, 2024 \[Thomas Peter/Reuters\]

An ‚Äòinsane and suicidal escapade‚Äô
---------------------------------

Western analysts have offered differing explanations for the Kursk offensive ‚Äì including the diversion of Russian troops and a psychological reset through seizing the initiative. ![](/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/AP24240624343613-1724950393.jpg?resize=770%2C513&quality=80)

Ukrainian historian Yuri Savchuk carries a road sign in Sudzha, Russia, on August 16, 2024 \[File:AP\]

*   [![John T Psaropoulos](/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/e97a12bd596e49388d5c4baa7421e7ce_6.jpeg?resize=96%2C96&quality=80)](/author/john_psaropoulos_2012510204426705651)
    
    By¬†[John T Psaropoulos](/author/john_psaropoulos_2012510204426705651)
    

Published On 29 Aug 202429 Aug 2024

Ukraine‚Äôs deep strikes against Russian military targets and its three-week-old ground offensive inside Russian territory have appeared to be yielding military and political results during the past week.

Russia was reported to be moving its aircraft back from airfields near the Ukrainian border while glide bomb attacks inside Ukraine were reported to have decreased. Life has the same value everywhere.‚Äù

Zelenskyy said he had discussed such a joint aerial defence with Lithuanian Prime Minister Ingrid Shimonite and Polish President Andrej Duda in Kyiv on August 24.

![Zelenskyy](/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/2024-08-29T152147Z_1900713370_RC2W89AC0M5A_RTRMADP_3_UKRAINE-CRISIS-JET-CRASH-1724945509.jpg?w=770&resize=770%2C513&quality=80)

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy appears next to an F-16, confirming the arrival of the first such fighter jet from its allies on August 4, 2024 \[Valentyn Ogirenko/Reuters\]

Taking the fight to Russia
--------------------------

While Ukraine seeks expanded authority and cooperation from its allies, it is also going its own way. It is believed prototypes of this missile may have been used against Russian-occupied Crimea in August 2023 to [destroy two S-400](/news/2024/2/12/for-ukraines-defence-industry-ambitions-the-skys-the-limit)
 air defence systems. Evidence that Moscow was scrambling elite units from Ukraine to defend home turf also mounted during the week.

An unnamed White House official told the Politico news website that ‚Äú90 percent of the planes that launch glide bombs‚Äù against Ukrainian front-line positions had been moved back inside Russia.

![INTERACTIVE-ATTACK_ON_KURSK_AUG_28-1724833592](/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/INTERACTIVE-ATTACK_ON_KURSK_AUG_20-1724833592.png?w=770&resize=770%2C962&quality=80)

(Al Jazeera)

The independent analysis website Frontelligence agreed that ‚Äúbetween the second half of June and mid-July, Russian forces relocated many valuable assets away from the Ukrainian border,‚Äù including planes and helicopters.

Ukrainian Colonel Vitaly Sarantsev told a joint news telethon broadcast by Ukrainian channels that the Kursk offensive had greatly reduced Russia‚Äôs use of aviation against northeastern Ukraine.

‚ÄúWe felt relief in tactical aviation,‚Äù he said on Sunday. If so, that would be a significant proportion of the more than 700,000 soldiers Russia is estimated to have in Ukraine.

The Washington, DC-based Institute for the Study of War (ISW), a think tank, estimated that Russia would need 60,000 soldiers to win back territory in Kursk once Ukrainian defences were dug. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy last week said it was a preemptive defence to prevent another Kharkiv-type invasion in the north.

But he also told Ukrainians it was ‚Äúa way to compensate for the deficit in long-range capabilities‚Äù.

For months, Zelenskyy has implored the United States to allow Ukraine to use the [ATACMS long-range rocket artillery](/news/2024/8/23/which-countries-weapons-is-ukraine-using-in-russia-incursion)
 it provides to strike airfields deep inside Russia. He also wants the US to release Britain and France, for whose Storm Shadow missiles the US provides components, to authorise their use in the same way.

Currently, the US allows Ukraine to use its weapons to counter battery fire within a limited range across the border but not to hit Russian airfields because it is afraid that this could draw the US into the war.

![INTERACTIVE-WHO CONTROLS WHAT IN SOUTHERN UKRAINE-1724833604](/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/INTERACTIVE-WHO-CONTROLS-WHAT-IN-SOUTHERN-UKRAINE-1724833604.png?w=770&resize=770%2C770&quality=80)

(Al Jazeera)

In a recent analysis, the ISW identified that ‚Äúat least 209 of 245 (more than 85 percent) known Russian military objects in range of ATACMS are not air bases‚Äù but ammunition depots, communications centres, army bases and command centres.

White House national security spokesman John Kirby told reporters on Monday that restrictions on the use of long-range weapons remain in place but ‚Äúwe‚Äôll keep the conversations with the Ukrainians going‚Äù to potentially revise them.

The European Commission, which does not command military assets, has openly supported a lifting of restrictions.

The European Union‚Äôs top diplomat, Josep Borrell, [repeated that support](/news/2024/8/29/eus-borrell-urges-ukraine-backers-to-lift-curbs-on-arms-use-inside-russia)
 on Monday and Thursday. ‚ÄúI reiterate that lifting restrictions on the use of capabilities against the Russian military involved in aggression against Ukraine, in accordance with international law, would strengthen Ukrainian self-defence, save lives and reduce destruction in Ukraine,‚Äù he said on Monday.

Russian officials bared their teeth against any such decision and hit out against the fact that both Brussels and Washington have allowed the use of US and European equipment in Ukraine‚Äôs Kursk offensive.

‚ÄúThe West does not want to avoid escalation."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Al Jazeera article, published on August 29, 2024, discusses Ukraine's ground offensive inside Russian territory, specifically in the Kursk region. <image:26> is not present in the article. The article mentions an incursion of Ukrainian troops into the Kursk region of Russia on August 7, 2024, and includes an image of a building on fire in Sudzha, Russia. <image:k> The article also mentions that Russia was moving its aircraft back from airfields near the Ukrainian border. The article also includes images of Ukrainian servicemen in Pokrovsk, Ukraine, and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. <image:j>

Content: The search result from Wikipedia discusses the 2024 Kursk offensive, which began on August 6, 2024, as part of the Russo-Ukrainian War. <image:26> The Armed Forces of Ukraine launched an incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast. The article mentions the involvement of Ukrainian, Russian, and North Korean forces, and provides casualty figures from both sides. The incursion led to a state of emergency in Kursk Oblast and the postponement of elections. The article also mentions the destruction of bridges and the capture of settlements.


From [Source](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c0q198zyppqo): 
Content: The BBC published an article on March 17, 2025, discussing the retreat of Ukrainian troops from the Kursk region. The article mentions that the roads were littered with destroyed military equipment, including tanks and armored vehicles. <image:4578>, <image:4583>. The article also includes a map showing the Ukrainian advance in August 2024 and the subsequent Russian control by March 16, 2025. <image:4581>.


From [Source](https://www.aljazeera.com/features/2024/8/29/russia-lashes-out-against-terrorist-incursion-in-kursk-pulls-back-planes):

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:26> This image shows destroyed Ukrainian tanks during Ukraine's incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:26>)
web_search("Ukraine Russia Kursk Oblast August 2024 tanks destroyed")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `reverse_search`
The reverse image search found the image in multiple sources. One source, from Sputnik Africa, published on October 17, 2024, reports that Ukraine has lost around 40 Leopard tanks since February 2022. The Moscow Times published an article on June 13, 2023, stating that Russia had captured German Leopard tanks in the Zaporizhzhia region. Defence Security Asia published an article on May 19, 2024, discussing the destruction of Leopard tanks in Ukraine. None of the sources mention Ukraine's incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024.

The sources include images of Leopard tanks <image:2767>, <image:2768>, <image:2769>, and <image:2776>.


### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss the 2024 Kursk offensive, which began on August 6, 2024, as part of the Russo-Ukrainian War. The Armed Forces of Ukraine launched an incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast. The BBC article, published on March 17, 2025, mentions destroyed military equipment, including tanks and armored vehicles, on the roads. The Al Jazeera article, published on August 29, 2024, discusses Ukraine's ground offensive inside Russian territory, specifically in the Kursk region.

The sources mention the involvement of Ukrainian, Russian, and North Korean forces, casualty figures, a state of emergency, and the postponement of elections. The BBC article includes a map showing the Ukrainian advance in August 2024 and the subsequent Russian control by March 16, 2025. The Al Jazeera article includes an image of a building on fire in Sudzha, Russia, and mentions Russia moving its aircraft back from airfields near the Ukrainian border. <image:26>, <image:4578>, <image:4583>, <image:4581>, <image:k>, <image:j>


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence confirms that Ukraine launched an incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024, and that destroyed military equipment, including tanks, was present on the roads. The reverse image search did not find the exact context of the image, but it did find images of destroyed tanks.

Based on the available evidence, the claim is likely true. However, the exact type of tanks in the image cannot be confirmed.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.



## Decision Options
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:26> This image shows destroyed Ukrainian tanks during Ukraine's incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:26>)
web_search("Ukraine Russia Kursk Oblast August 2024 tanks destroyed")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `reverse_search`
The reverse image search found the image in multiple sources. One source, from Sputnik Africa, published on October 17, 2024, reports that Ukraine has lost around 40 Leopard tanks since February 2022. The Moscow Times published an article on June 13, 2023, stating that Russia had captured German Leopard tanks in the Zaporizhzhia region. Defence Security Asia published an article on May 19, 2024, discussing the destruction of Leopard tanks in Ukraine. None of the sources mention Ukraine's incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024.

The sources include images of Leopard tanks <image:2767>, <image:2768>, <image:2769>, and <image:2776>.


### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss the 2024 Kursk offensive, which began on August 6, 2024, as part of the Russo-Ukrainian War. The Armed Forces of Ukraine launched an incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast. The BBC article, published on March 17, 2025, mentions destroyed military equipment, including tanks and armored vehicles, on the roads. The Al Jazeera article, published on August 29, 2024, discusses Ukraine's ground offensive inside Russian territory, specifically in the Kursk region.

The sources mention the involvement of Ukrainian, Russian, and North Korean forces, casualty figures, a state of emergency, and the postponement of elections. The BBC article includes a map showing the Ukrainian advance in August 2024 and the subsequent Russian control by March 16, 2025. The Al Jazeera article includes an image of a building on fire in Sudzha, Russia, and mentions Russia moving its aircraft back from airfields near the Ukrainian border. <image:26>, <image:4578>, <image:4583>, <image:4581>, <image:k>, <image:j>


## Elaboration
The evidence confirms that Ukraine launched an incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024, and that destroyed military equipment, including tanks, was present on the roads. The reverse image search did not find the exact context of the image, but it did find images of destroyed tanks.

Based on the available evidence, the claim is likely true. However, the exact type of tanks in the image cannot be confirmed.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence confirms that Ukraine launched an incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024, and that destroyed military equipment, including tanks, was present on the roads. The reverse image search did not find the exact context of the image, but it did find images of destroyed tanks.

The claim is likely `true`.

* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.

* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:26> This image shows destroyed Ukrainian tanks during Ukraine's incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast in August 2024."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:26>)
```

### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss the 2024 Kursk offensive, which began on August 6, 2024, as part of the Russo-Ukrainian War. The Armed Forces of Ukraine launched an incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast. The BBC article, published on March 17, 2025, mentions destroyed military equipment, including tanks and armored vehicles, on the roads. The Al Jazeera article, published on August 29, 2024, discusses Ukraine's ground offensive inside Russian territory, specifically in the Kursk region.

## Final Judgement

The claim is likely `true`.

While the reverse image search did not pinpoint the exact context of the image, it did find images of destroyed tanks, supporting the claim's general assertion.
